Elliott,

The good:
There are some nice tsuba in your in your folder. I
like the Sukeyoshi and the one labeled Saotome.

The bad:
Photos #19 & #20 are of a shiiremono (mass produced)
tsuba. It might even be one of the better modern
chinese repros. For study's sake, look up Mito
Shiiremono.

The ugly:
There is no sharpness or crispness to the design. The
nanako (little beads) are crudely spaced. The figures
are poorly cut, and gold washed.


Curran



--- Elliott <elliott@...> wrote:

> Dear group,
> 
> First let me say it is a priviledge to have access
> to all of your 
> opinions. I can only hope that thru years of study
> that I may obtain 
> some of the knowledge this group possesses.
> 
> Now my question..........If you would go to
> 'elliotts photos' and look 
> at numbers 19 and 20 (click on them), I am trying to
> determine the 
> school and time (early, middle, late Edo) of this
> Tsuba. I have taken 
> a shot at the characteristics of this piece. Just
> point me in a 
> direction to study.
> 
> Thank you all,
> 
> Elliott
